Names of team members" institute: "Wharton School of Business" date: "2022-11-17" output: xaringan::moon_reader: css: xaringan-themer.css lib_dir: libs nature: ratio: "16:9" highlightStyle: github highlightLines: true countIncrementalSlides: false --- ## A statement of the overall goal / research question Our project will demonstrate that the `praise` package is by far the best `R` package. # Section title # Hello World - Click the `Render` button to compile your presentation # Quarto - The presentation is created using the `quarto` package - Use `##` or `#` to start a new slide # incremental ::: incremental - Thing 1 - and another - the last thing - with math $\frac{1}{2}$ ::: # Layouts You can use plain text - or bullet points .footnote\[ \[\*\] And add footnotes\] # Two columns ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](img/confetti.jpg) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} words here ::: ::: ## {background-image="img/confetti.jpg" background-size="contain"} # Code ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # a boring regression model <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars) tidy(model) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 × 5 term estimate std.error statistic p.value 1 (Intercept) -17.6 6.76 -2.60 1.23e- 2 2 speed 3.93 0.416 9.46 1.49e-12 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} glance(model) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 × 12 r.squared adj.r.squa…¹ sigma stati…² p.value df logLik AIC BIC devia…³ 1 0.651 0.644 15.4 89.6 1.49e-12 1 -207. 419. 425. 11354. # … with 2 more variables: df.residual , nobs , and abbreviated # variable names ¹​adj.r.squared, ²​statistic, ³​deviance # ℹ Use `colnames()` to see all variable names ``` ::: ::: # Plots ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](presentation_files/figure-html/plot-iris-1.png){width=80%} ::: ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ # Tables If you want to generate a table, make sure it is in the HTML format (instead of Markdown or other formats), e.g., ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}

````` ::: ::: # Some text {background-image="https://www.purina.com.au/-/media/project/purina/main/breeds/dog/dog_boston-terrier_desktop.jpg?h=475&la=en&w=825&hash=DC3F38D08CCE086118327D827C002A62" background-size="cover"} # Math Expressions You can write LaTeX math expressions inside a pair of dollar signs, e.g. \$\alpha+\beta\$ renders $\alpha+\beta$. You can use the display style with double dollar signs: $$\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i$$ $$\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i$$ Limitations: 1. The source code of a LaTeX math expression must be in one line, unless it is inside a pair of double dollar signs, in which case the starting `$$` must appear in the very beginning of a line, followed immediately by a non-space character, and the ending `$$` must be at the end of a line, led by a non-space character; 2. There should not be spaces after the opening `$` or before the closing `$`.. # Feeling adventurous? - Want to find out more about `quarto`? See https://quarto.org/. - You are welcomed to use the default styling of the slides. In fact, that's what I expect majority of you will do. You will differentiate yourself with the content of your presentation. - But some of you might want to play around with slide styling. This provides some solutions for this that: https://quarto.org/docs/output-formats/html-themes.html.
